监管美国公司在华投资的规则已经具有一种幻影的性质：总是迫在眉睫，总是延迟。近几个月来，关于这个话题的争论已经加速到了高潮。三月份，美国财政部和商务部提交了有关潜在规则的报告。下个月，乔·拜登总统的安全顾问杰克·沙利文在一次演讲中对这项政策表示支持。拜登先生预计将随后发布行政命令。美国的盟友正在考虑类似的限制。 6 月 20 日，欧盟委员会宣布了计划，尽管计划很模糊，但将在年底前提出一项倡议。

当拜登的行政命令确实出现时，它可能会集中投资于三种“力量倍增”技术：先进半导体、人工智能（ AI ）和量子计算。禁令和通知要求的具体排列尚不清楚，但这些规则只会影响美国对中国企业的一小部分投资，这些投资截至 2021 年底价值超过 1 万亿美元。研究公司荣鼎集团 (Rhodium Group) 的数据显示，过去十年，美国公司在中国进行了 1200 亿美元的外国直接投资和 620 亿美元的风险投资（见图表）。

对美国资本进行地缘政治制动并不是一个全新的想法。一些与中国军方有联系的公司禁止投资者投资， 《CHIPS法案》禁止接受其补贴的公司进行可能有利于中国半导体行业的投资。支持者表示，对外投资规则是美国拼凑而成的贸易限制的必要延伸：如果出口管制阻止中国公司购买一些军民两用技术，而入境投资审查则阻止他们抢购制造这些技术的美国公司，那么美国资本就不应该获准资助该技术在中国的开发。

对美国环球投资者施加限制会带来风险。一是制定过于宽泛的规则，限制资本流动，并在没有充分理由的情况下给投资者带来负担。财政部官员保罗·罗森 (Paul Rosen) 今年 5 月表示，这些规则将重点关注“具有专有技术和专业知识的投资资金”。欧洲领导人表示，需要采取限制措施来防止“技术泄露”。但弄清楚哪些类型的投资存在漏洞是很棘手的。一家希望在中国扩大先进计算业务的科技巨头可能会违反这一标准，但投资公司及其最终投资者的情况就不那么简单了。私募股权基金可能会收购一家公司，但不会提供运营优势，而小型风险投资可能会带来值得保护的技术专长。

据智库安全与新兴技术中心称，2015-21年，包括芯片制造商英特尔和高通的风险投资部门在内的美国投资者参与的融资轮次，占中国人工智能公司筹集的1100亿美元资金的37% 。美国养老基金对回报的渴望使它们成为此类投资的受益者。根据 PitchBook 的数据，纪源资本(GGV Capital) 是中国人工智能公司最活跃的美国投资者之一。我们对公开披露信息的分析表明，在过去十年中，总资产超过 6000 亿美元的 6 个美国养老基金和捐赠基金已向ggv Capital 的基金承诺了约 20 亿美元。

此类投资带来的国家安全风险是一个悬而未决的问题。同样重要的是，如果美国投资者受到限制，中国投资者是否可以在任何情况下更换资金。一些人认为，拜登政府应该先给出更坚定的答案，然后再要求资产管理公司和养老基金在其投资组合中寻找中国科技公司的踪迹，而资产管理公司和养老基金通常会接触到数百家全球投资基金。

另一个危险是任务蔓延。在拜登的领导下，经济政策和国家安全政策变得越来越难以区分。去年，总统指示美国外国投资委员会（ CFIUS ）考虑包括供应链弹性在内的更广泛因素，该委员会是美国境内投资监管机构，近年来案件数量激增。根据国家利益的广泛标准审查对外投资可能会变得难以处理。由于担心投资官僚主义日益严重，一些人建议改用现有的制裁规则。

尽管拜登最初的对外投资政策预计将比任何所谓的“反向外国投资委员会”都要狭窄，但白宫以外不乏鹰派人士将对外投资筛选视为产业政策的工具。据荣鼎集团称，2021年，两党国会议员提出了一项法案，对境外投资进行广泛筛选，影响了超过40%的美国对华投资。上个月发布了该法案的更新版本。它将不仅限制先进技术的投资，还限制汽车制造和制药等行业的投资，并赋予白宫扩大清单的权力。

贸易限制的扩散并不仅限于美国边境。一些人将拜登行政命令的延迟归因于难以在盟国中争取对新规则的支持。七国集团（ G 7）世界领导人的盛会在五月份召开，但在这个问题上只做出了一些温和的承诺。全球范围内很少有国家对境外投资设置限制，但对境内投资的审查正在迅速增加。欧洲正在加强保护：欧盟27 个成员国中有 18 个制定了此类规则，涵盖了越来越多样化的“战略”行业。该委员会的对外投资规则计划对日益复杂的繁文缛节构成威胁。

对西方在华投资的影响取决于任何规则的最终范围。美国的投资已经在下降。自2018年高峰以来，流向中国的风险投资已大幅下降80%以上。随着中国商业环境的恶化，目前还没有出现逆转的迹象。本月，美国大型风险投资公司红杉资本宣布，将在 2024 年之前剥离其中国业务。目前，鹰派政策制定者可以放心，中国正在为他们做他们的工作。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:56 GMT /内容/cbrj2klfvgrspcl2rahlfa4fp1r2r72v https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/americas-plan-to-vet-investments-into-china Why is China blocking graphite exports to Sweden?

2020年初，瑞典电池制造商注意到了一些令人担忧的事情。他们的中国供应商不再能够向他们出售石墨，这是一种对锂离子电池生产至关重要的矿物。瑞典人认为问题会过去。然而三年过去了，随着中国在欧洲电池行业的投资激增，瑞典企业仍然基本上被隔绝。 2020年中国对瑞典的两种石墨出口几乎消失。 2021年和2022年，它们完全消失了。

尽管中国商务部尚未发布正式禁令，但许多中国石墨出口商面临着形同虚设的禁令。一家公司被告知，中国监管机构不再发放向瑞典出口石墨的许可证。鉴于中国供应了全球60%以上的天然石墨以及几乎所有的人造石墨，这种情况给依赖中国生产电池用石墨阳极的生产商敲响了警钟。来自中国的供应中断可能会扰乱供应链、提高成本并扰乱生产。对于该行业刚刚起步的瑞典来说，全面禁止出口可能会造成严重损害。欧盟委员会在关于此事的唯一官方声明中表示，今年早些时候，中国石墨出口的枯竭“正在对欧洲电池生产产生负面影响，而电池生产是欧盟绿色转型的关键部门”。

当中国寻求因政治争端而惩罚国家时，它经常会施展自己的影响力。从 2020 年开始，澳大利亚正式禁止从澳大利亚进口煤炭（今年取消了限制），并对龙虾实施了非正式禁令，这给几乎完全依赖龙虾的澳大利亚卖家带来了毁灭性后果。迎合中国人的胃口。中国官员经常威胁要禁止向美国出口稀土等矿产，作为对制裁的报复。锂和钴等电池矿物的出口禁令变得更加普遍。据主要由富裕国家组成的经合组织称，中国是限制向可再生能源转型所需材料供应的最大罪魁祸首。

掌握瑞典石墨禁令背后的原因可能与处理它同样重要。乍一看，该禁令似乎是由近年来中国和瑞典之间的许多小外交争端之一引发的。 2019 年底，瑞典笔会（一个言论自由倡导组织）向在中国被监禁的出版商兼持不同政见者桂民海颁奖。中国驻斯德哥尔摩大使馆立即对瑞典发出威胁。瑞典公民桂先生自2015年在泰国被中国特工绑架以来一直处于两国争端的中心。2020年和2021年，熟悉桂先生案件的人士认为这是石墨限制的动机。这些人现在相信，这不仅仅是为了一个奖项而发生的小争吵。

随着对瑞典的石墨出口大幅下滑，中国在整个欧洲的电池和电动汽车投资总额却大幅上升。中国最大的电池制造商宁德时代(CATL)去年斥资80亿美元在匈牙利建厂，这是该国有史以来最大的外国投资之一。中国公司正在波兰建造规模较小但类似的工厂。与此同时，对这两个国家的石墨出口猛增。 2022 年，匈牙利进口了价值超过 2.3 亿美元的一种石墨，而五年前该材料的进口额仅为数千美元。

碰巧的是，瑞典的 Northvolt 是欧洲新兴电池行业中最具竞争力的公司之一。该公司已开始在欧洲扩张，并将获得建设新工厂的补贴。目前尚不清楚石墨禁令对 Northvolt 产生了什么影响（如果有的话）。但人们相信，在争夺市场份额的竞争比以往任何时候都更加激烈之际，它有可能增加成本。了解中国石墨禁令的内部人士开始质疑，随着中国在欧洲站稳脚跟，这些非官方措施是否旨在阻碍欧洲的创新。 5月，中国普泰莱公司宣布投资13亿美元建设欧洲最大的阳极工厂。它将成为瑞典电池行业的核心供应商。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:55 GMT /内容/u1v6a1091679lbu47rcfbbpr1a15a0to https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/why-is-china-blocking-graphite-exports-to-sweden Europe’s last finishing school targets anxious executives

三杯马提尼的午餐可能已经结束，但商务晚宴仍将继续，这一前景让一些高管感到恐惧。对于那些觉得多排餐具和酒杯令人困惑的人，或者总是忘记哪一个餐盘是自己的，我们可以帮助您解读隐藏的礼仪规则。在俯瞰日内瓦湖的山上，一家公司为高管们提供了额外的社交礼仪，以增强他们的信心——也许还有他们的职业生涯。

位于蒙特勒上方的 Villa Pierrefeu 学院成立于 1954 年，是欧洲最后一所精修学校。它的课程从一到六周不等，涵盖从座位优先、茶水服务礼仪到黑带级礼仪挑战（例如用刀叉吃香蕉）的所有内容。从历史上看，它的大多数学生都是为婚姻市场做准备的年轻女性。如今，随着社会规范的放松和对此类教育的需求减弱，Villa Pierrerefeu 正在探索新的客户群：企业高管。该学院校长 Viviane Néri 表示，它不再是一所完成学校，而是一所“入门学校”。

为期五天的“欧洲餐饮艺术”课程（费用约为 5,000 瑞郎，即 5,570 美元）包括菜单规划、英式餐桌布置和法式餐桌礼仪等模块。学生们仔细记录技术、公司法和银行等领域的葡萄酒搭配和餐具布置工作。有些人在那里是为了掌握外国文化。印度一家广告网络的负责人艾哈迈德·阿夫塔布·纳克维 (Ahmed Aftab Naqvi) 表示，在 Villa Pierrerefeu 的工作经历帮助他“了解了文化、习俗、传统和礼仪的多样性”。另一些人则希望自己优雅的举止能够赢得同事的尊重。 “我想升职，”加州一家科技巨头的一名员工说道。

有些教训多年来没有改变。学生们被告知，一旦用餐完毕，他们可以将亚麻餐巾放在右侧（法式）或左侧（英式）。但在其他方面，学校必须适应。内里女士改变了课程以适应专业人士，取消了旧的九个月文凭，并提供全年课程，客户可以在年假期间参加。未能适应的学校不得不关闭，或者扮演不那么光鲜亮丽的角色。 Le Manoir 曾是洛桑的一所精修学校，如今成为利乐的国际总部。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:55 GMT /内容/bqtjv09qi06sqas1mr16298pb21d97bk https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/europes-last-finishing-school-targets-anxious-executives India leads a boom in orders for passenger jets

在巴黎和范堡罗之间轮流举办的年度航展上，传统习俗比比皆是。一是游客的观察结果：一座闪闪发光的首都，在跑道尽头的薄雾中可以看到埃菲尔铁塔，比一座不起眼的英国小镇更可取，因为它的主要景点是两年一度的航展。另一个问题是对那些布满商用喷气式飞机、战斗机、直升机和其他高科技装备的飞机跑道的炎热天气的抱怨。

最可预测的惯例是，欧洲航空航天巨头空中客车公司将趁机在本土停机坪上向波音公司发起打击，波音公司是其在全球大型客机供应双头垄断中的美国竞争对手。 6月19日，它并没有让人失望。在众多规模较小的交易中，最引人注目的是印度低成本航空公司靛蓝航空 (IndiGo) 的一笔巨额交易。该公司订购了 500 架空客A 320 系列窄体喷气式飞机，将于 2030-35 年交付，这是有史以来最大的一笔订单。波音公司唯一的重大反击是确认了印度航空 2 月份订购的 190 架 737 max s 竞争机型和 30 架宽体长途喷气机的订单。

如果说波音公司感到沮丧的话，那么其商业营销主管达伦·赫尔斯特(Darren Hulst)并没有表现出来。在巴黎公布的订单是航空公司急于扩大机队规模的一部分，以应对疫情消退后航空旅行恢复快速增长的情况。 Hulst 先生指出，去年范堡罗航展后的 10 个月内，波音公司的订单量增加了 1,100 多架飞机，到 2042 年，全球航空公司将需要 42,600 架新飞机。

运营商迫切需要新金属。波音和空客的积压订单总数约为 12,000 架。印度航空的需求量几乎与靛蓝航空一样多；该公司在巴黎确认将购买 250 架空客飞机。 5 月份，欧洲最大的航空公司瑞安航空 (Ryanair) 订购了 300 737最大型飞机。去年年底，美国联合航空公司订购了 200 架飞机，由空客公司和波音公司分配。在巴黎航展上，利雅得航空展示了一架涂有醒目的紫色制服的波音 787。这家由沙特阿拉伯主权财富基金资助的新航空公司已订购 39 架波音广受欢迎的宽体喷气式飞机，计划于 2025 年开始运营。以沙特首都为基地，旨在向国际开放该国旅游。预计很快将订购大量短途飞机。

在财富的同时，问题仍然存在。首先，空客和波音能否增加在 covid-19 期间低迷的产量来满足需求？空客公司的A 320 飞机交付率在疫情期间下降至每月 40 架，目标是到 2025 年每月交付 75 架。加强供应链并不容易，尤其是在许多公司解雇了成本最高、经验最丰富的员工的情况下。

另一个问题仍然困扰着印度。随着这个世界上人口最多的国家变得更加富裕，那里的需求猛增。波音公司表示，印度占该地区 90% 客流量的南亚将成为未来二十年全球增长最快的航空旅行市场。中国拥有 4,000 架飞机，而印度的机队数量只有 700 架。靛蓝航空目前运营着大约 300 架飞机，还将增加 1,330 架飞机，为已经成为全球第三大国内航空市场的国家提供服务。

然而，控制着国内约 60% 市场份额的 IndiGo 的快速扩张是付出了代价的。该公司最近一个财年是连续第四个财年出现亏损。它的成功部分归功于其他印度航空公司的失败。其竞争对手捷特航空 (Jet Airways) 在 2019 年破产，另一家竞争对手 Go First 则于上个月倒闭。它们的停飞应该能让幸存的运营商提高票价，但官员们明确表示，这种上涨必须受到限制。

其结果是，在巨额新订单带来的兴奋背后，隐藏着对一些买家是否会继续高歌猛进的担忧。航展的另一个传统是专家们用牙齿吸吮空气，想知道未来是否真的像数字所暗示的那样美好。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 13:46:55 GMT /内容/18rj5h8n6ndobq1p35fpl076uvv8aa00 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/india-leads-a-boom-in-orders-for-passenger-jets “Scaling People” is a textbook piece of management writing

太多的管理书籍都建立在一个已经达到极限的模糊概念之上。从页边空白的深度就可以看出作者是多么努力地写出这篇论文。他们的封面明亮而活泼。他们的标题要么包含“奋斗”和“点燃”等充满动感的词语，要么催生出一些可怕的新合成词，如“压力”或“魅力”。他们决心向除了实际企业之外的任何地方的老板们学习：白蚁、狩猎采集者、诺瓦克·德约科维奇、沙拉酱。大多数管理头衔的潜规则似乎是回避管理的实际实践。

那么，读一本打破常规的书真是一种解脱。它落地时发出令人生畏的撞击声。它看起来和感觉就像一本教科书。它充满了练习和模板。而且它的重点毫无疑问是实用的。 《Scaling People》的作者是科技行业资深人士克莱尔·休斯·约翰逊 (Claire Hughes Johnson)，她在谷歌工作了十多年，之后于 2014 年加入数字支付独角兽 Stripe，担任首席运营官。到 2021 年，该公司员工人数从 160 人增加到 7,000 多人。在一个充满程序员、创造者和梦想家的世界里，她的工作就是让一切顺利进行。

本书的大部分内容都是一本创建休斯·约翰逊女士所说的操作系统的手册——一套文档、指标和流程，为制定决策和提高绩效提供了一致的框架。其中有一个关于规划的部分，提供了关于设定良好目标以及决定会议和审查节奏的建议，从而为公司设定正确的鼓点。还有一个关于招聘人员的问题，从建立招聘渠道到面试过程，再到引进新员工的任务。其中有关于提高团队绩效和提供反馈的章节。

“Scaling People”是硅谷的产物。它致力于解决快速增长的问题；它的背景是创始人、开发人员和产品团队之一。对于高度监管行业的现任者或公共部门官僚机构的雇员来说，扩大规模的问题似乎非常遥远。例如，Stripe 早期决定举办名为“Capture the Flag”的编程竞赛，这有助于建立其作为优秀开发人员聚集地的声誉。老牌公司需要付出更少的努力来提高潜在候选人的知名度，但在创新方面建立声誉可能会更加困难。

但这种做法所依据的见解——在这种情况下，让候选人在申请过程中做实际工作并填补招聘渠道，而不是等待职位空缺——是可以转移的。本书的大部分内容都致力于解决困扰所有行业和公司的问题。

除此之外，休斯·约翰逊女士还提供了如何召开有效会议的建议；其中包括在开始时进行一轮“签到”（例如，让每个人都说出他们想从会议中得到什么），以便人们集中注意力，并让小组中最安静的成员尽早参与。她提供了有关如何进行绩效评估、您可以并且应该将哪些决策委托给其他人以及如何使高绩效员工免于倦怠的建议。这一切都是令人耳目一新的务实。

这些策略的背后有一个明确的哲学，那就是化隐为显。这意味着要清楚如何做出具体决定：这是一个协商一致的过程还是一个专制的过程？这意味着把事情写下来：通过阐明 Stripe 的文化，初创公司可以让潜在的加入者清楚公司的规范是什么。这意味着说别人没有说的话，尤其是当这些事情导致功能障碍时。

它还意味着了解您自己的行为和偏好。休斯·约翰逊女士长期以来一直保留着一份“与克莱尔合作”的文件，其中向她的团队新成员详细说明了他们可以期待什么：她喜欢如何做出决定，她对信息的反应速度有多快，她希望从他们那里得到什么一对一会议。

她的建议并不适合所有人。某些企业文化会过分强调流程。但对于每个老板来说，都有一些发人深省的事情。你的床头柜上可能堆满了关于德约科维奇先生可以教你什么领导力或从蛋黄酱中学到的教训的书籍。本书试图做一些更加原创和有用的事情：让你成为一名更好的管理者。 ■

; Thu, 22 Jun 2023 09:25:57 GMT /内容/jnllp6cbfdhjsle1k43td05bqp6bls78 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/22/scaling-people-is-a-textbook-piece-of-management-writing Doctor Walmart will see you now

穿着长长的白大褂，戴着听诊器，举止和蔼、舒缓，并且热衷于讨论“人口健康管理”和“以患者为中心”的医学，罗纳德·瑟西似乎是初级保健医生的柏拉图式理想。他最不寻常的地方是他工作的地方：一个紧凑的设施，配有检查室、牙医办公室、放血实验室和X光室，藏在阿肯色州西北部的一家沃尔玛里。自 2019 年以来，沃尔玛已在 5 个州开设了 32 家此类“健康中心”；到明年年底，该公司计划将这一数字增加一倍以上，并扩展到另外两个州。

沃尔玛并不是唯一一家扩大医疗产品供应的大公司。今年早些时候，亚马逊收购了 One Medical，这是一家在美国各城市设有办事处的礼宾服务机构（意味着客户每年支付会员费）。折扣零售商 Dollar General 与经营流动医疗诊所的 DocGo 建立了合作伙伴关系，并在田纳西州的三家商店启动了试点计划。 Walgreens 和CVS都是零售药店，拥有强大的初级保健产品；去年，超过 550 万名患者到CVS MinuteClinic 就诊，使其成为美国最大的医疗服务提供商之一；今年早些时候， CVS完成了对 Oak Street Health 的收购，后者是一家专注于老年人的初级保健提供商，在 21 个州设有办事处。这些公司在医疗业务中看到了什么？答案既简单又复杂，符合美国拜占庭式且充满租金的医疗保健系统。

简单的答案就是钱。美国人在健康方面的支出惊人：2021年约占GDP的18%，远远超过富裕国家约10%的平均水平，是韩国等人口更健康、寿命更长的国家的两倍多。预计未来八年美国人的支出每年增长 5.4%（见图表），到 2031 年将超过经济增长，占GDP的近 20%。其中大部分支出将来自医疗补助和医疗保险等联邦计划分别覆盖穷人和 65 岁以上老年人的医疗费用。

复杂的部分反映了保险公司（包括医疗补助和医疗保险）支付保险费用方式的变化；以及消费者愿意获得它的方式的变化。从保险公司开始。主要的支付模式是按服务付费，保险公司为医生的每次就诊或手术进行报销。它的优点是简单。它的缺点是它鼓励医疗消费，但在大多数情况下对结果漠不关心：无论患者是否健康，医生都会得到相同的报酬。

然而，从 2016 年到 2021 年，“替代支付模式”的医疗保健支出比例从 29% 上升到 40%。在 2022 年的一项调查中，大多数支付者认为这些支付模式，尤其是那些让医生分享保持患者健康的好处的支付模式将会增加。这种方法被称为“基于价值的医疗”（ VBC ），是《平价医疗法案》的产物。它激励医生保持患者的健康，例如，如果患有慢性病的患者服药并住院，医生可以让他们分享节省的费用，而不是简单地为每次进行的手术付费。公司押注他们可以通过这种模式比旧模式赚更多的钱。

推出或扩大初级保健产品的零售商也在押注消费者的习惯。咨询公司埃森哲最新的消费者脉搏调查显示，近三分之一的消费者（其中超过三分之一的 18 岁至 35 岁消费者）愿意在杂货店或大型零售商处获得医疗服务。超过 90% 的客户会信任零售商提供他们的医疗数据。零售商相信，这种信任和便利性（75% 的美国人居住在距离 Dollar General 不到 5 英里的范围内，90% 的美国人居住在距离沃尔玛不到 10 英里的范围内）是一个成功的组合。

更好的技术可以改善VBC ，既可以为保险公司提供更多健康措施来判断医生的成功，也可以为医生提供更好的方式与患者保持联系。例如，Walmart Health 和 OneMedical 使用应用程序向患者显示其病史，包括即将到来的预约以及何时需要重复处方。这两家公司还拥有内部药房，可以引导患者前往药房。而初级保健医生是患者整个医疗护理事实上的协调者和看门人。一些人担心VBC可能会激励保险公司拒绝转介和必要的护理，并保留积蓄。但如果病人病情加重，他们也会分担这些费用。

管理这种下行风险将很棘手。 VBC所需的主动护理和患者接触，使用智能手机可能比不使用智能手机更便宜，但它并不便宜。医疗服务提供者需要投资技术，但也可能需要通过重复的电话和家访来掌握患者的情况——这些是应用程序无法做到的事情。犯错的公司将会陷入困境。那些做得对的人将增加他们在美国臃肿且低效的医疗保健系统中流动的巨额资金中所占的份额，并且顺便也可能让人们保持更健康。 ■

; Wed, 21 Jun 2023 13:44:15 GMT /内容/frm1ko1r4757ifn2e3b7l9jp7j0ravrl https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/21/doctor-walmart-will-see-you-now The new king of beers is a Mexican-American success story

国王死了。 ¡雷伊万岁！今年夏天，随着自称为美国“啤酒之王”22年的百威淡啤 (Bud Light) 被墨西哥啤酒 Modelo Especial 取代，酒吧里响起了欢呼声。为战败者想想吧。很少有哪个品牌复兴的努力会像百威淡啤的营销人员与变性社交媒体明星建立联系，结果却成为美国文化战争的受害者那样犯下如此严重的错误。从好的方面来说，它提供了一个研究鲜为人知的成功故事的机会。星座品牌 (Constellation Brands) 是一家十年前才进入酿酒业的美国公司，它为我们提供了如何发动墨西哥裔美国人风格的老式企业叛乱的一课。

熊彼特应该申报利益。他在墨西哥生活了很多年，一生的一部分时间都是伴随着一种或另一种墨西哥啤酒度过的。 Modelo Especial 很少是其中之一。在边境以南，它没有太大的声望。然而在美国，同样的啤酒、同样的口味甚至超越了它更知名的姐妹品牌 Corona Extra。这是因为，从简单的商业角度来看，星座公司从制造到分销再到零售，一切都做得很好。最重要的是，它抓住了拉丁裔消费者日益增长的力量。

Modelo Especial 的故事始于反垄断。不是那种尺寸本身就被视为禁忌的新奇观念，而是认为购买竞争对手会导致更高价格的老派观念。这可以追溯到2013年，当时百威啤酒的比利时所有者百威英博斥资200亿美元收购了墨西哥最大的啤酒制造商Grupo Modelo，该公司的Corona和Modelo Especial等品牌是边境以北百威淡啤的竞争对手。美国司法部介入。 It determined that, in order to maintain competition, AB InBev should divest Modelo's entire US business to Constellation, which was then a relatively little-known wine and spirits seller worth $8.1bn. ( AB InBev kept the Grupo Modelo business in Mexico and the rest of the world.) Today Constellation is worth $45bn and is one of the most respected consumer-goods companies in America.

Bump Williams, a consultant who first noticed that in the four weeks to June 3rd, at-home sales of Modelo Especial had shot past Bud Light in dollar terms, uses a vivid expression to describe the way Constellation nurtured the brand. He calls it “feeding the hot hand”. When the company noticed that the beer was taking off, it did not let a perception that Corona was the front-runner distract it. It threw its weight behind the mood of the marketplace.

Its priority was to ensure that supply met demand. That involved making a huge bet on Mexico. When Constellation acquired the brands, it resolved to brew them south of the border. Since then it has increased its production capacity in Mexico fourfold, at a cost of $6.4bn—more than the $4.8bn it paid for the brands in 2013. It is not stopping there. It plans to invest up to a further $4.5bn over the next three fiscal years, boosting capacity by more than 70%. Investing in Mexico has not been without setbacks. In 2020 protesters, backed by Andrés Manuel López Obrador, Mexico's populist president, voted in a plebiscite to stop Constellation from building a factory close to the border because of concerns about water shortages. So it moved the factory to Veracruz, on Mexico's wetter east coast, with the president's blessing.

Distribution in America was the next challenge. To start with, Constellation focused on bringing Modelo Especial to a few cities with big Hispanic communities, such as Los Angeles and Chicago. After the brand took off there, it expanded farther afield. It built brand awareness one step at a time and worked closely with its distributors to ensure that supply kept flowing. Once in shops, Constellation focused on showcasing the Modelo brand. “They're wine guys, they know the value of display,” says Mr Williams. They also got pricing right. Instead of foisting large increases on consumers, Constellation made incremental price rises. For many years, Modelo Especial has been the fastest-growing beer in America, says Scott Scanlon of Circana, a market-research firm. Yet more impressive is that it is a premium brand, rather than a budget one, at a time when wallets are stretched—and a full-bodied beer, rather than a low-calorie one, when waistlines are.

The reasons for its consumer appeal are twofold. First is advertising. Unlike Bud Light's, it is not gimmicky. It tells stories of ordinary people who have overcome hardship. That has helped it pull off the trick of remaining authentically Mexican even as it joined the big-beer league. Second is the market itself. Its core consumers are Latinos, who have growing economic power in America. According to McKinsey, a consultancy, it is not just their population that is increasing faster than the American average. So is their spending power. If America's Latinos were their own country, they would have had the third-fastest-growing economy after China and India during the past decade.

The flamin' hot hand

This power may cast a halo effect on other products of Mexican descent. Tequila looks likely to overtake vodka as America's best-selling spirit. Grupo Bimbo, a Mexican multinational that is America's biggest baker is, like Constellation, a respected consumer-goods company. In a sign of the times, a new film, “Flamin' Hot”, tells the story of how a Mexican-American janitor convinced Frito-Lay, owned by PepsiCo, to produce spicy Cheetos to win over the Hispanic market, reviving its business. (The snack's true genesis is disputed, but its popularity is in no doubt.)

Modelo Especial may yet lose its crown as Bud Light gets over its current crisis. Yet the fizzing growth of the Mexican-American brand suggests it could eventually gain a more lasting lead. It is lamentable for business in general that America's cultural divide has done so much damage to Bud Light's reputation. But the consolation is that Modelo Especial's success suggests the cultural divide between America and Mexico is narrowing. ■

; Tue, 20 Jun 2023 17:01:47 GMT /content/1tqd44jr826osd73dv6ck02dthp46r35 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/20/the-new-king-of-beers-is-a-mexican-american-success-story The upside of workplace jargon

A n idea to run up the flagpole: jargon gets an overly bad press. Not the kind of jargon that involves using the words “flagpole” and “run up”, but the kind that binds teams together. The kind that is exemplified by the term “nub”. In the very unlikely event that you find yourself on board a submarine but are not a member of the crew, you will be a nub.

A nub is a “non-useful body”—someone who uses up oxygen, food and space and offers nothing in return. A nub is someone who is not on the team, and the opacity of jargon gives the word extra bite. Only insiders know what it means.

Useful crew members have their own names. This cast of characters includes nukes, coners, shower techs and other bubbleheads whose jobs may include looking after Sherwood Forest. (If you need to ask, you are a nub.) Although submarines are unusual environments, the use of jargon to signify specific practices, objects and people is prevalent in workplaces everywhere.

Some of this jargon is not much more than slang. The “blue goose” is what White House staffers call the travelling presidential lectern. The “grid” is the nickname for the diary of planned policy announcements by the British government. Doctors have a private vocabulary for patients when they are out of earshot. “ Status dramaticus ” is how some medics diagnose people who have not much wrong with them but behave as though death is nigh; “ash cash” is the fee that British doctors pocket for signing cremation forms.

Such shared language is not exactly high-minded but it does serve a useful purpose—creating a sense of tribe and of belonging. Each company generates its own particular lexicon. The GE logo is also known as “the meatball” by people inside the industrial firm. At Stripe, a digital-payments company, hiring-committee meetings are called “tropes”. A “fourth leader” is what journalists at The Economist call lighthearted opinion articles. No one knows why; it is usually the fifth of five editorials. But the knowing is enough. The code confers membership.

Jargon can spread for practical reasons as well as cultural ones. The airline industry has the usual slang, from “deadheads” (off-duty crew on a commercial flight) to “George” (a common nickname for the autopilot). But codifying knowledge in agreed ways can be a serious business. Well over 1,000 passengers and crew lost their lives between 1976 and 2000 in accidents where misunderstandings over language were found to have played a role. Pilots use highly standardised and scripted terminology in order to reduce the scope for potentially fatal errors.

Terms can arise as a way of increasing efficiency. A paper published last year, by Ronald Burt of Bocconi University and Ray Reagans of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, looked at how jargon emerges naturally among groups. It describes an experiment in which volunteers are assigned to teams. Each team member is separately assigned a set of symbols, and one symbol is common to all of them. Team members must quickly identify this shared symbol by sending messages to each other that describe what they have been given.

To start with, the teams use quasi-sentences and generic words to get across what they are seeing (one symbol “looks like its leg is out in a kicking motion”). Soon enough everyone in the team is calling it “kicking man” or “kicker”. As rounds progress a tacitly agreed vocabulary allows teams to identify the common symbol more and more quickly. Different teams alight on different forms of jargon for each symbol, but the effect is the same: everyone knows what is meant and things get done faster.

Jargon can be desperately unhelpful. The criminal-justice system is made more intimidating, to victims and suspects alike, by confusing terminology. Conversations between doctors and patients go much better when everyone understands each other. One reason why management jargon arouses so much irritation is because it usually substitutes for something that was doing the job perfectly well. No one hears the words “Let's talk about it later” and feels baffled. Plenty of people do hear the phrase “Let's put a pin in it” and wish they had a sharp object to hand.

There is an awful lot of non-useful blather out there, in other words. But the fact that jargon emerges spontaneously and repeatedly suggests it has its merits. In the right circumstances it can help build a culture and act as a useful shorthand. If you think all jargon is worthless, it may be time to circle back. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 13:20:26 GMT /content/hkocf4fcrg0b08vlqn3rsvbdj27i6ms8 https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/15/the-upside-of-workplace-jargon Which sport is the best business?

T HE 2023 finals of America's National Basketball Association ( NBA ) and Europe's football Champions League were both history-making events, in rather different ways. On June 12th the basketball contest crowned a small-city team that had never before won a championship, the Denver Nuggets. They defeated an unlikely challenger in the Miami Heat, the last-seeded team among the eight playoff teams in its conference. Had Miami won, that would have been a first for such a lowly side. Meanwhile, the UEFA Champions League final, held on June 10th, featured a powerhouse from Britain, Manchester City, defeating a mainstay of European football, Italy's Inter Milan.

European and British football leagues generally let teams spend as much as they want on players, as long as they do not lose too much money. More successful sides tend to earn more money, and so have more cash to splurge on star players—which in turn translates into more success on the pitch, and so on. The week before its Champions League triumph, Man City snatched the English FA Cup, beating Manchester United, another deep-pocketed team. Man United and Man City have won 20 out of the past 31 English Premier League titles; the Champions League (or its predecessor, the European Cup) has been won by Real Madrid and AC Milan, Inter's arch-rival, 21 out of 68 times.

Across the Atlantic, meanwhile, the sports world's most lucrative competition, the National Football League ( NFL , which involves the non-soccer variety) has a hard salary cap, leading to more parity among teams. The top two squads have won only 12 of 56 Super Bowls, the annual tournament's final round. The penalty for breaking the NBA ’s current $124m salary cap was bumped up in 2011 and again this year in a revenue-sharing deal negotiated between the players' union and owners. “The new deal is basically trying to prevent superteams,” says Brian Windhorst of ESPN , a television network. And it seems to be working. The Economist ’s analysis of NBA data shows that a broader set of teams have indeed made it to the playoffs in recent history. In the five years to 2023, 29 of the NBA ’s 30 squads made the league's knockout stage at least once (the Charlotte Hornets are the exception). That has not happened since the five years to 2008, itself an unusually competitive period.

American sporting socialism, then, appears to lead to more competitive contests than Europe's winner-takes-all approach. But do more competitive leagues make for better business? Here the evidence is mixed. On the one hand, unpredictability may drive interest—why watch when you know who will win? The possibility of an underdog's success might help small teams develop devoted fan bases. On the other hand, people love a winner. Mr Windhorst notes that seasons in which big-name teams like the Boston Celtics have dominated were some of the NBA ’s most money-making years. In 2022, when the finals pitted the Celtics against San Francisco's Golden State Warriors, another star team, the league raked in record revenues of $10bn.

Another structural difference between American and European sport is easier to correlate with their moneymaking potential. Unlike European football, where teams can be promoted or relegated across various tiers of leagues, American sports tend to be “closed”—there is no way for new teams to accede to the top tournament. “The Europeans see this as fundamental to the organisation of team sports,” explains Stefan Szymanski of the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor. Count all the tiers, and more than 1,000 clubs across Europe hope to compete in the Champions League. The NBA ’s 30 or the NFL ’s 32 make for more concentrated markets. And concentration leads to riches. (That explains why the threat of a breakaway league of elite teams hangs over European football.)

Last year the NFL ’s revenues reached $19bn, nearly three times as much as the English Premier League, which probably boasts more fans worldwide than all the American sports put together (see chart). As a result, American teams, which partake in the bonanza, fetch higher valuations. Over the past decade the value of the average NFL and NBA teams has grown by more than 300% and 600%, respectively, compared with a rise of 170% for America's booming stockmarket. A willingness to sacrifice profits for participation makes Europe's sport look European, after all. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 13:20:26 GMT /content/ggoobetsq6tl12phbo9vpci6nubrji9c https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/15/which-sport-is-the-best-business Why self-storage is turning into hot property

A NYONE ASKED to come up with their favourite literary home is spoiled for choice: Pemberley, Brideshead, Blandings, Jay Gatsby's mansion, to name a few. The same holds true for workplaces on television: Los Pollos Hermanos, Dunder Mifflin and the swish Waystar Royco offices, for instance. Ask someone to come up with their favourite fictional storage unit, and expect a blank stare (the most ardent Neal Stephenson fans may recall the one where Hiro Protagonist lives in “Snow Crash”).

Ubiquitous and unremarkable, self-storage solves a deeply American problem: what to do with too much stuff. A bunch of empty rooms near a highway is not the sexiest part of a property portfolio. Yet few property assets have matched their performance lately (see chart).

One reason is more people moving house. (Ron Havner, former boss of Public Storage, the biggest self-storage firm, said that people seek his services for “the four Ds”: death, divorce, disaster and dislocation.) Amid covid-19, anyone living in a house or flat with no spare rooms had to convert an existing one to a home office or gym. That meant clearing out whatever was there. Many were reluctant to bin things, especially early on when nobody knew how long self-isolation would last. The alternative was to stash it in storage. Over the past three years self-storage occupancy rates have risen from around 90% to as much as 96%. Demand has been especially high in Florida, Texas and the sunbelt, where people flocked in search of larger homes and laxer lockdowns.

High demand, in turn, has given landlords pricing power. Rent bumps went from around 8-9% every six months before the pandemic to as much as 35%, according to Spenser Allaway of Green Street, an advisory firm. Facilities managers can get away with this because customers tend to be “sticky”: they may shop around and choose a facility based on price and proximity, but once their stuff is in they seldom bother moving it. As Stephanie Wright of New York University explains, “Individuals tend to think, 'I'll park my stuff here for a month or two,' but the average rental duration is in excess of a year.”

Storage firms have also embraced dynamic-pricing software. Knowing up-to-the-minute market rates allows them to avoid undercharging customers. This is of a piece with the sector's operational efficiency (a small staff keeps labour costs low; preparing a unit for a new customer requires little more than a quick sweep) and with its drive to modernise. Indoor, climate-controlled facilities are becoming the norm. “The days of the old drive-up with a rickety fence and a Doberman for a security system, that's not going to cut it anymore,” says Tim Garey of Cushman Wakefield, a property consultancy.

The last factor behind self-storage's outperformance is constrained supply. Whereas the amount of available square footage rose by more than 15% from 2016 to 2019, labour shortages, high construction costs and supply-chain snags have limited new construction in the past few years. That may change as these bottlenecks ease. Even then, the self-storage business may slow but not collapse. As long as Americans keep buying things, they will continue to need places to put it. ■

; Thu, 15 Jun 2023 13:20:26 GMT /content/d9p2odi30coln1e70lk05uql2emchbti https://www.economist.com/business/2023/06/15/why-self-storage-is-turning-into-hot-property How long will the travel boom last?

R EVENGE HOLIDAYS are in full swing and the travel industry is cashing in. After a rocky few years, the urge to splurge on airline tickets and hotels is set to bring in bumper earnings. Tour operators are inundated with bookings; hotel chains are raking in record profits. EasyJet has raised its earnings forecasts twice this year; IAG and Ryanair have both returned to profit for the first time since the start of the pandemic, and Singapore Airlines is handing out some of its record profits as bonuses worth eight months' salary. With air fares rising faster than inflation, global airline bosses now expect $9.8bn in net income this year, more than double the amount initially forecast, according to the International Air Transport Association, an industry body.

The holiday boom has lifted the outlook for international travel. Worldwide tourist arrivals this year are expected to reach up to 95% of pre-pandemic levels, up from 63% in 2022, estimates the UN ’s World Tourism Organisation. Share prices of travel companies, which tumbled in early 2022 amid fears of rising inflation and a looming recession, are soaring again (see chart). High prices have not deterred sunseekers so far. “People are prioritising travel over other discretionary spending,” says David Goodger of Oxford Economics, a consultancy. Still flush with cash saved during lockdowns, many are splashing out on holidays, even as they trim spending on clothes or dining out.

A few factors will determine how long the good times roll on for. Some have to do with the industry's supply side: shortages of airport staff, soaring jet-fuel costs and crumbling IT systems, which buckled under the weight of demand last year, leading to hours-long flight delays or cancellations at short notice. A quarter of all flights in America were scrapped or delayed last summer. Such meltdowns erode trust. They are also costly. Southwest Airlines estimates that the cancellation of nearly 17,000 flights in December led it to incur around $800m in losses.

A bigger question concerns demand. After a glorious summer, appetite for holidays could come crashing down as fast as it has risen. Although America's Federal Reserve has paused interest-rate rises, it is expected to lift rates again in coming months. As the Fed and other central banks in rich countries keep fighting stubborn inflation, holidaymakers may eventually throw in the beach towel.

Chinese tourists, the third-biggest group after Americans and Germans in 2019, according to Oxford Economics, may not pick up the slack. Since covid restrictions in China were eased last year, nearby destinations such as Macau and Thailand have proved popular. Yet Chinese enthusiasm for far-flung spots remains tepid. Accor, a hotel giant, estimates that around three-quarters of Chinese travellers this year will opt for “staycations” instead.

A lull in holidaymaking would be bad news for a heavily indebted industry already facing escalating expenses and recovering from past losses. Airlines alone lost $138bn in 2020. Moody's, a credit-rating agency, expects their labour costs to increase by nearly a fifth this year. Short-staffed hotels are struggling to fill positions despite raising wages. In Britain, wage bills are 15% higher than before the pandemic. After a years-long holiday, day-to-day economic reality may be setting in for the travel industry. ■
